pullRequest.body:
We define and establish basic API for swap matrices. `Matrix.swap R i j` is the matrix that, when multiplying on the left, swaps the `i`-th and `j`-th row.

From "Formalizing the Bruhat-Tits tree"

Co-authored-by: Judith Ludwig <ludwig@mathi.uni-heidelberg.de>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body: messageFile.md
Are you aware of Equiv.toMatrix, or whatever the actual name is? Certainly, we have a way of converting `Equiv.swap i j` into a matrix, which I think might unfortunately make much of this PR moot.

> Are you aware of Equiv.toMatrix, or whatever the actual name is? Certainly, we have a way of converting `Equiv.swap i j` into a matrix, which I think might unfortunately make much of this PR moot.

I was not aware of `PEquiv.toMatrix` and indeed [PEquiv.toMatrix_swap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Matrix/PEquiv.html#PEquiv.toMatrix_swap) shows that it gives the `Matrix.swap` defined here. This might simplify some of the proofs, but I still think we need the API here. Am I misunderstanding you?
Thanks for the suggestions @eric-wieser!
Thanks @Ruben-VandeVelde, I adapted your suggestions.
messageFile.md

### PR summary [24b1322dc8](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19812/commits/24b1322dc8e5cb127758fd361cfc15dec8ea8452)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.Swap` (new file)|1398|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ conjTranspose_permMatrix`
`+ conjTranspose_swap`
`+ mulSingle_comp_equiv`
`+ mul_swap_apply_left`
`+ mul_swap_apply_right`
`+ mul_swap_of_ne`
`+ swap_comm`
`+ swap_mulVec`
`+ swap_mulVec_apply`
`+ swap_mul_apply_left`
`+ swap_mul_apply_right`
`+ swap_mul_of_ne`
`+ swap_mul_self`
`+ transpose_permMatrix`
`+ transpose_swap`
`+ vecMul_swap`
`+ vecMul_swap_apply`
`++ map_swap`
`++ swap`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Thanks for the suggestions @eric-wieser .

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#21143~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#21141~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

maintainer merge

since I've looked a little too much at this now.

Thanks for your patience!
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by eric-wieser.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13387165846/job/37386391374)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13387165846/job/37386391081)
Thanks! This seems reasonable; just some small comments below.
Thanks! This seems reasonable; just some small comments below.

I think at the very least we should define this in terms of `(Equiv.swap _ _).toPEquiv.toMatrix`, as then it doesn't need `Ring` or even `Neg`, and will work on matrices of `Nat`.

I'm still not sure whether we want `swap` at all, but I think it will be easier to tell once it's written in terms of the existing API.
Indeed, using `PEquiv.toMatrix` significantly improves things. I generalized some of the lemmas to that setting and now just specialize.
Do you have an idea where these should go? Note that `Pi.induction_add` is not available in `Data.Matrix.PEquiv` because `Algebra.BigOperators.Pi` is not available.
If you insist, I can define this in the `PEquiv` setting as well, this has nicer def-eqs though since here `val = inv` is def-eq.
Can you use the notation here? Also, can you add the `conjTranspose` version too?
Maybe this should just be `simp`, then you wouldn't need the lemma below?
Why g and k as names for matrices? The rest of the file seems to use M and N
I think `swap_comm` for consistency (and clearer to me as well)
With this number of arguments, I would recommend new-style `induction` rather than `induction'`
Maybe `swap_mulVec_single_{left,right}`?
Same
This feels backwards to me, but perhaps @Vierkantor can opine on which direction this import should go.

(Sorry, feeling ill since this weekend so this is probably not very coherent.) The import graph of `ConjTranspose` is very gray. And via `Matrix.Basis` we'll additionally get products and spans of modules and algebras. Is `assert_not_exists Algebra` true on the master branch?

Sorry, I was busy recently, so only coming back to this now. `assert_not_exists Algebra` does not hold on master, because `Mathlib.Algebra.Star.Module` imports it.
Edit: Turning the imports around yields `large-import` with a 14% increase, so maybe the other way round was better?

Hmm... Indeed `Algebra.Star.Module` already brings in `LinearAlgebra.Prod` so I suppose for the short term we'd better stick to your original approach of importing `Basis` into `ConjTranspose`. In the long term we would have to do a lot more untangling before this file gets a nice set of imports. But that long term should not apply to your PR.
Thanks, changed it back.

```suggestion
@[to_additive (attr := elab_as_elim)]
```
since this is an induction principle.
I've created #21089 which perhaps makes this more useful.
While I agree this looks reasonable, I don't understand the implications of your comment for this PR.
After trying to apply it, I found it had no use :)

I think this might be slightly more useful as
```lean
lemma toPEquiv_toMatrix_mulVec [Fintype n] [DecidableEq n]
    [NonAssocSemiring Î±] (Ïƒ : m â‰ƒ n) (a : n â†’ Î±) :
    Ïƒ.toPEquiv.toMatrix *áµ¥ a = a âˆ˜ Ïƒ
```
though it's ok to have both as long as you prove one with the other.
Could you add the conjTranspose lemma too?

```suggestion
lemma Pi.induction_mul {Î¹ M : Type*} [Finite Î¹] [DecidableEq Î¹] [CommMonoid M] (p : (Î¹ â†’ M) â†’ Prop)
    (f : Î¹ â†’ M) (hone : p 1) (hmul : âˆ€ f g, p f â†’ p g â†’ p (f * g))
    (hsingle : âˆ€ i m, p (Pi.mulSingle i m)) : p f := by
  cases nonempty_fintype Î¹
```
These look like good `simp` lemmas. Can you add the `vecMul` versions too?
They can't be `simp` because of `Matrix.mulVec_single` (which I think looks questionable as a `simp` lemma).

I've opened #21091, which hopefully is a slightly better form for that lemma; though it probably won't help here.

Was the error "simp can prove this" or "simp can reduce the LHS"? Ideally it would be the former...
It is `simp` can reduce the LHS. I can make it the former though by adding more lemmas I think.

Hm, possibly
```
@[simp]
lemma swap_apply_apply_left (i j k : n) :
    swap R i j k i = Pi.single (f := fun _ â†¦ R) j 1 k := by
  simp [swap, Pi.single_apply, Equiv.swap, Equiv.swapCore]
  aesop

@[simp]
lemma swap_apply_apply_right (i j k : n) :
    swap R i j j k = Pi.single (f := fun _ â†¦ R) i 1 k := by
  simp [swap, Pi.single_apply, Equiv.swap, Equiv.swapCore]
  aesop
```
helps. Then it becomes
```
lemma swap_mulVec_single_left (i j : n) (r : R) :
    swap R i j *áµ¥ Pi.single i r = Pi.single j r := by
  ext k
  simp [Pi.single_apply]
```
Do you think that's worth it?
Probably not in it's current form. I'll locally merge #21091 and see if that's enough to result in a confluent `simp` set.
This one also looks like a good simp lemma.

Convention for indunction principles is to drop the `h`s:
```suggestion
    (f : Î¹ â†’ M) (one : p 1) (mul : âˆ€ f g, p f â†’ p g â†’ p (f * g))
    (mulSingle : âˆ€ i m, p (Pi.mulSingle i m)) : p f := by
```
You might want to manually `to_additive` this so that the names are `add` and `single` for the additive version.

```suggestion
@[elab_as_elim, to_additive existing]
```
or whatever the syntax is.
Strictly speaking this name is backwards; I've created #21108 to fix the existing names that this copies.

```suggestion
  (Equiv.swap i j).permMatrix
```
seems to be the same thing.

I don't know if the name is worth the extra import? Also, I don't really understand the purpose of [Equiv.Perm.permMatrix](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Matrix/Permutation.html#Equiv.Perm.permMatrix).

I think the import is pretty cheap, and inserting it makes `permMatrix` more discoverable.

Your `transpose` and `conjTranspose` lemmas could then also be stated for the more general `permMatrix` case, and invoked directly here.
Done.

```suggestion
lemma Pi.single_induction {Î¹ M : Type*} [Finite Î¹] [DecidableEq Î¹] [AddCommMonoid M]
```
I would suggest

```suggestion
lemma Pi.mulSingle_induction {Î¹ M : Type*} [Finite Î¹] [DecidableEq Î¹] [CommMonoid M] (p : (Î¹ â†’ M) â†’ Prop)
```
@fpvandoorn, do you think `to_additive` should change variable names?
Yeah, that seems reasonable if someone wants to implement this. This is #11462

```suggestion
  aesop (add unfold stdBasisMatrix)
```
Same below
Can_ you move them to L. 789 and split the `variable` into two? one half before your lemmas, the rest after
Eric just renamed a bunch of lemmas in this file. Can you merge master to check your code still compiles?

```suggestion
lemma toMatrix_toPEquiv_mulVec_apply [Fintype n] [DecidableEq n]
    [NonAssocSemiring Î±] (Ïƒ : m â‰ƒ n) (i : m) (a : n â†’ Î±) :
    (Ïƒ.toPEquiv.toMatrix *áµ¥ a) i = a (Ïƒ i) := by
```
Same below

Could you split this PR into two? One adding:
* the small lemmas added to various files
* this new file

It's good practice to add new definitions in their own PR, separate from cleanup/API filling concerns
Have done so.
I've attempted to solve the merge conflicts for you.
Thanks a lot @eric-wieser! This PR went of my radar, fixed the remaining errors.

```suggestion
This is a thin wrapper around `(Equiv.swap i j).permMatrix`.
```
Shouldn't `g` be a rectangular matrix here (and perhaps in all the other lemmas too)?

```suggestion
lemma mulSingle_comp_equiv {m n : Type*} [DecidableEq n] [DecidableEq m] [One Î±] (Ïƒ : n â‰ƒ m)
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(LinearAlgebra/Matrix): swap matrices
